Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is a prominent material for radiative cooling due to its promising optical properties in the mid-infrared spectral region as well as its fabrication easiness. Even thoug...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is a prominent material for radiative cooling due to its promising optical properties in the mid-infrared spectral region as well as its fabrication easiness. Even though several works have reported that the mid-infrared emissivity of a PDMS film can be increased by surface modification, there is still room for further enhancement through global optimization. Here, we designed and fabricated the thin PDMS film patterned with two-dimensional gratings to obtain the highest emissivity in the wavelength range from 8 to 13 μm. A surrogate-model-based optimization was performed, and the optimum structure exhibited the averaged emissivity value of 0.99 in the wavelength of 8–13 μm, which is the highest value reported to date among polymer-based radiative coolers. For real-world applications, we also developed the fabrication method that is repeatable and applicable for various surfaces using a flexible master mold.
meta.name: citation_abstract

div.h6:
Ultrahigh emissivity of grating-patterned PDMS film from 8 to 13
μ
m wavelength regime

ul.li:
Ultrahigh emissivity of grating-patterned PDMS film from 8 to 13
μ
m wavelength regime

1
Department of Mechanical Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
, Daejeon 34141,
South Korea

2
Center for Extreme Thermal Physics and Manufacturing, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology

div.div:
Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is a prominent material for radiative cooling due to its promising optical properties in the mid-infrared spectral region as well as its fabrication easiness. Even though several works have reported that the mid-infrared emissivity of a PDMS film can be increased by surface modification, there is still room for further enhancement through global optimization. Here, we designed and fabricated the thin PDMS film patterned with two-dimensional gratings to obtain the highest emissivity in the wavelength range from 8 to 13
μ
m. A surrogate-model-based optimization was performed, and the optimum structure exhibited the averaged emissivity value of 0.99 in the wavelength of 8–13
μ
m, which is the highest value reported to date among polymer-based radiative coolers. For real-world applications, we also developed the fabrication method that is repeatable and applicable for various surfaces using a flexible master mold.

The radiative cooling provides passive cooling in atmospheric conditions through the radiative heat transfer between the surface on the earth and the deep space.
1–3
1. S. Catalanotti, V. Cuomo, G. Piro, D. Ruggi, V. Silvestrini, and G. Troise, Sol. Energy
17
, 83 (1975).
https://doi.org/10.1016/0038-092X(75)90062-6
2. A. P. Raman, M. A. Anoma, L. Zhu, E. Rephaeli, and S. Fan, Nature
515
, 540 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nature13883
3. L. Zhu, A. Raman, and S. Fan, Appl. Phys. Lett.
103
, 223902 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4835995
A material selectively emitting radiation in the air transmittance region enables passive radiative cooling because emitted radiative power from the material surface can exceed the summation of absorbed radiative power and gained conductive and convective power. Intuitively, the key factor of this technology is to enhance the emissivity in the wavelength range from 8 to 13
μ
m where the air is transparent as well as the major part of the radiative emission is concentrated. As a material to realize this technology, polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) silicone elastomer has drawn much attention due to its promising radiative cooling compatible optical properties, fabrication easiness, and affordable material cost.
4,5
4. A. Srinivasan, B. Czapla, J. Mayo, and A. Narayanaswamy, Appl. Phys. Lett.
109
, 061905 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4961051
5. L. Zhou, H. Song, J. Liang, M. Singer, M. Zhou, E. Stegenburgs, N. Zhang, C. Xu, T. Ng, Z. Yu, B. Ooi, and Q. Gan, Nat. Sustainability
2
, 718 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-019-0348-5
After Srinivasan
et al.
4
4. A. Srinivasan, B. Czapla, J. Mayo, and A. Narayanaswamy, Appl. Phys. Lett.
109
, 061905 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4961051
determined the dielectric function of PDMS and demonstrated that the thin PDMS film can perform as a selective emitter, the field investigation of radiative cooling was followed by using 100-
μ
m-thick PDMS coated on a silica substrate.
6
6. J.-L. Kou, Z. Jurado, Z. Chen, S. Fan, and A. J. Minnich, ACS Photonics
4
, 626 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsphotonics.6b00991
More recently, by utilizing 150-
μ
m-thick PDMS manufactured by the roll-to-roll process, all-day radiative cooling was accomplished under the urban environment.
5
5. L. Zhou, H. Song, J. Liang, M. Singer, M. Zhou, E. Stegenburgs, N. Zhang, C. Xu, T. Ng, Z. Yu, B. Ooi, and Q. Gan, Nat. Sustainability
2
, 718 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-019-0348-5

Given that the emissivity above the bulk PDMS cannot be obtained with planar PDMS surfaces, several studies have been conducted to further enhance the emissivity by modifying surfaces. Lee and Luo
7
7. E. Lee and T. Luo, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
194
, 222 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.02.015
theoretically demonstrated that the temperature of solar cells can be reduced by coating the surface with a pyramid-structured PDMS radiative cooler. Flexible photonic-architectured PDMS by Lin
et al.
8
8. S. Lin, L. Ai, J. Zhang, T. Bu, H. Li, F. Huang, J. Zhang, Y. Lu, and W. Song, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
203
, 110135 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110135
and triangular arrayed PDMS by Jeong
et al.
9
9. S. Y. Jeong, C. Y. Tso, Y. M. Wong, C. Y. H. Chao, and B. Huang, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
206
, 110296 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110296
were also fabricated by the imprint process. Although both works demonstrated the averaged emissivity of 0.98 in the wavelength region of 8–13
μ
m, there is potential for further enhancement by means of global optimization. For example, Lin
et al.
8
8. S. Lin, L. Ai, J. Zhang, T. Bu, H. Li, F. Huang, J. Zhang, Y. Lu, and W. Song, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
203
, 110135 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110135
have not performed the structure optimization thoroughly. In addition, they implemented a surface treatment on the silicon mold using trichlorosilane, which should be eliminated in the commercial applications due to toxicity. For example, Jeong
et al.
9
9. S. Y. Jeong, C. Y. Tso, Y. M. Wong, C. Y. H. Chao, and B. Huang, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
206
, 110296 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110296
decided dimensions of geometry through the parametric study with one design variable. In addition, their radiative cooler is not compatible to flexible or curved surfaces because of the existence of a rigid silica substrate in the middle of the sample.

In this work, we introduce a grating microstructure that is extensively used to improve the performance of thermal-radiation-based devices (e.g., solar thermal absorbers,
10,11
10. H. Wang and L. Wang, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
158
, 127 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2014.11.015
11. J. Choi, M. Kim, K. Kang, I. Lee, and B. J. Lee, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
209
, 129 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.01.028
thermophotovoltaics,
12,13
12. B. Zhao, L. Wang, Y. Shuai, and Z. M. Zhang, Int. J. Heat Mass Transfer
67
, 637 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijheatmasstransfer.2013.08.047
13. N. Vongsoasup, M. Francoeur, and K. Hanamura, Int. J. Heat Mass Transfer
115
, 326 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijheatmasstransfer.2017.07.070
and radiative coolers
14,15
14. A. Hervé, J. Drévillon, Y. Ezzahri, and K. Joulain, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
221
, 155 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.09.015
15. L. Long, Y. Yang, and L. Wang, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
197
, 19 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.04.006
) by tailoring the spectral emissivity. Our aim is to achieve the significantly enhanced emissivity in the wavelength region of 8–13
μ
m by modifying the surface of a thin PDMS film with two-dimensional (2D) grating. To optimize the grating structure, a surrogate-model-based optimization has been applied. By utilizing an artificial neural network (ANN) model to build the surrogate model,
16
16. J. Seo, P.-H. Jung, M. Kim, S. Yang, I. Lee, J. Lee, H. Lee, and B. J. Lee, Sci. Rep.
9
, 15028 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-51407-2
we can substantially reduce the computational expenses in the optimization process. In addition, we also develop the fabrication method that is repeatable and applicable for various surfaces using a flexible master mold. The fabricated grating-patterned PDMS film results in an averaged emissivity value of 0.99, which is the highest value among the polymer-based radiative coolers.
4–6,8,9,17–21
4. A. Srinivasan, B. Czapla, J. Mayo, and A. Narayanaswamy, Appl. Phys. Lett.
109
, 061905 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4961051
5. L. Zhou, H. Song, J. Liang, M. Singer, M. Zhou, E. Stegenburgs, N. Zhang, C. Xu, T. Ng, Z. Yu, B. Ooi, and Q. Gan, Nat. Sustainability
2
, 718 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-019-0348-5
6. J.-L. Kou, Z. Jurado, Z. Chen, S. Fan, and A. J. Minnich, ACS Photonics
4
, 626 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsphotonics.6b00991
8. S. Lin, L. Ai, J. Zhang, T. Bu, H. Li, F. Huang, J. Zhang, Y. Lu, and W. Song, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
203
, 110135 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110135
9. S. Y. Jeong, C. Y. Tso, Y. M. Wong, C. Y. H. Chao, and B. Huang, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
206
, 110296 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110296
17. Y. Zhai, Y. Ma, S. N. David, D. Zhao, R. Lou, G. Tan, R. Yang, and X. Yin, Science
355
, 1062 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aai7899
18. J. Mandal, Y. Fu, A. C. Overvig, M. Jia, K. Sun, N. N. Shi, H. Zhou, X. Xiao, N. Yu, and Y. Yang, Science
362
, 315 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aat9513
19. A. Aili, Z. Y. Wei, Y. Z. Chen, D. L. Zhao, R. G. Yang, and X. B. Yin, Mater. Today Phys.
10
, 100127 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mtphys.2019.100127
20. D. Fan, H. Sun, and Q. Li, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
195
, 250 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.03.019
21. A. R. Gentle and G. B. Smith, Adv. Sci.
2
, 1500119 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1002/advs.201500119
The physical mechanism responsible for such a high emissivity value will be discussed later.

As illustrated in
Fig. 1
, the proposed structure consists of a 2D PDMS grating, a PDMS thin film, and a Ag mirror. Four design variables, i.e., a grating period (Λ), grating width (
w
g
), grating thickness (
t
g
), and thin-film thickness (
t
f
), are used to optimize the emissivity in the wavelength region of 8–13
μ
m. Hereafter, we will refer to this configuration simply as PDMS grating. For modeling and optimization, one should set boundaries and constraints of design variables first. Considering the wavelengths of interest (i.e., 8–13
μ
m), the ranges of Λ and
w
g
are chosen to be between 2 and 50
μ
m. The grating width should be naturally smaller than the period. The boundary ranges of rest two design variables are set to be 3–6
μ
m for
t
g
and 20–100
μ
m for
t
f
considering fabrication feasibility. The upper boundary of
t
f
has been set to be 100
μ
m since the emissivity of the PDMS film becomes nearly constant beyond this value.
5
5. L. Zhou, H. Song, J. Liang, M. Singer, M. Zhou, E. Stegenburgs, N. Zhang, C. Xu, T. Ng, Z. Yu, B. Ooi, and Q. Gan, Nat. Sustainability
2
, 718 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-019-0348-5
The design constraints of
w
g
/
t
g
>
0.6
and
Λ
−
w
g
>
3
μ
m are added for assuring the stability of the fabricated patterns. A detailed fabrication process will be explained later.

FIG. 1.
Schematic of a grating-patterned PDMS film atop an Ag mirror. Four design parameters are also indicated.

In the designing process, the performance of a PDMS grating is evaluated based on the averaged emissivity in the wavelength region of 8–13
μ
m. To compute an emissivity spectrum (
ε
λ
), an open-source rigorous coupled-wave analysis (RCWA) software
22
22. V. Liu and S. Fan, Comput. Phys. Commun.
183
, 2233 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2012.04.026
was used. Permittivity spectra required for RCWA computation were calculated using Lorentz–Drude models,
23
23. Z. M. Zhang,
Nano/Microscale Heat Transfer
(
McGraw-Hill
, 2007).
which could be obtained from earlier publications, i.e., PDMS from Srinivasan
et al.
4
4. A. Srinivasan, B. Czapla, J. Mayo, and A. Narayanaswamy, Appl. Phys. Lett.
109
, 061905 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4961051
and Ag from Rakić
et al.
24
24. A. D. Rakić, A. B. Djurišić, J. M. Elazar, and M. L. Majewski, Appl. Opt.
37
, 5271 (1998).
https://doi.org/10.1364/AO.37.005271

Because the genetic algorithm (GA), a well-known global optimization technique,
25
25. D. E. Goldberg and J. H. Holland, Mach. Learn.
3
, 95 (1988).
https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1022602019183
requires numerous numbers of performance estimation, a surrogate modeling using an artificial neural network (ANN)
16
16. J. Seo, P.-H. Jung, M. Kim, S. Yang, I. Lee, J. Lee, H. Lee, and B. J. Lee, Sci. Rep.
9
, 15028 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-51407-2
is employed to reduce the intrinsically high computational cost of RCWA. The constructed surrogate network model predicts the averaged emissivity in the 8–13
μ
m range by taking four design variables, that is, [Input: (
Λ
,
w
g
,
t
g
,
t
f
) → Output:
ε
̃
avg
]. In brief, the current surrogate network model consists of four layers with 10 nodes and requires a total of 1239 samples (i.e., 1239 RCWA computations) in the model training process to minimize a mean squared error of prediction by utilizing a cross-validation method.
26
26. M. Stone, J. R. Stat. Soc. Ser. B
36
, 111 (1974).
https://doi.org/10.1111/j.2517-6161.1974.tb00994.x
In this method, a random 5% of samples are used for validation at each step and the rest of the samples serve as model training. The cross-validation method can reduce an over-fitting effect.
27
27. G. C. Cawley and N. L. C. Talbot, J. Mach. Learn. Res.
11
, 2079 (2010).
Accordingly, we achieve an average of absolute value of the relative error (i.e.,
|
ε
̃
avg
/
ε
avg
−
1
|
¯
) for all validation steps less than 0.02% at a convergence stage.

As mentioned earlier, the genetic algorithm (GA)
25
25. D. E. Goldberg and J. H. Holland, Mach. Learn.
3
, 95 (1988).
https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1022602019183
has been employed in the optimization process, whose objective is to maximize the averaged emissivity predicted on the surrogate network model (i.e.,
ε
̃
avg
). To support the discrete optimization of the GA, a simple gradient descent optimizer was also used after reaching a local optimum of the GA. As a result, we obtained the best emitting PDMS grating. Design variables for the optimal structure are listed in
Table I
. The averaged emissivity of the optimal PDMS grating is 0.99, which exceeds the highest emissivity value of the 1239 training samples, 0.98. This also verifies that the surrogate network model can estimate an unknown response in the void space among sample data. It is also worthwhile to mention that the optimization using a surrogate model is more cost efficient than the method that directly couples the GA with RCWA simulation. At least 5000 times of performance computation are required for the optimization of the PDMS grating. Since only 1239 samples were used for the training process, the proposed optimization method using the surrogate model can reduce the computational cost more than 75%.

TABLE I.
Design variables of the optimal and fabricated structures.

To fabricate the optimal PDMS grating with the improved applicability, one should develop the fabrication method to readily transfer the patterned PDMS film to an arbitrary surface. In addition, to maintain the intrinsic infrared properties of PDMS, one should avoid the use of extra chemicals. Here, the SU-8 mold and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate are employed to transfer the 2D patterns on a PDMS film with precise control of the four design parameters.

The specific fabrication processes are illustrated in
Fig. 2
. Before SU-8 was spin coated on the PET substrate, the surface of PET was oxygen plasma treated (BD-10AS High frequency generator, Electro-Technic Products) to improve the wettability and obtain a uniform coating of photoresist. The bare SU-8 layer, which serves as an adhesive layer between the SU-8 mold and the PET substrate, was made on the PET substrate. The depth, width, and period of the SU-8 hollow-grating mold fabricated by conventional photolithography reflect the height, width, and period of the PDMS grating, respectively. Accordingly, at the step shown in
Fig. 2(a)
, three design variables (i.e., Λ,
w
g
, and
t
g
) are decided. A PDMS prepolymer mixed with a 10:1 weight ratio of base and curing agent (Sylgard 184, Dow Corning) was spin coated on the SU-8 mold at 500 rpm for 60 s and cured at 65 °C for 4 h on a hot plate [see
Fig. 2(b)
]. As a reflector of solar irradiation, a 200-nm-thick Ag film (i.e., Ag mirror) was deposited on the Si wafer using an electron-beam evaporator. Since the longest penetration depth of Ag in the wavelength range of 8–13
μ
m is about 13 nm, the 200-nm-Ag-coated Si can be safely regarded as a bulk Ag plate. In order to bond the cured PDMS to the Ag mirror, a 10:3 mixture of the PDMS base and the curing agent (i.e., bonding layer) was spin coated on the cured PDMS at 6000 rpm for 200 s.
28
28. R. W. R. L. Gajasinghe, S. U. Senveli, S. Rawal, A. Williams, A. Zheng, R. H. Datar, R. J. Cote, and O. Tigli, J. Micromech. Microeng.
24
, 075010 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0960-1317/24/7/075010
After the cured PDMS was attached to the Ag mirror, the bonding layer was cured at the room temperature for 48 h, as shown in
Fig. 2(c)
. We have confirmed that the variation in the weight ratio of the bonding layer would not affect the spectral emissivity (refer to Fig. S1 in the
supplementary material
). Finally, when the PET substrate was gently separated, the PDMS grating could be released from the SU-8 mold [see
Fig. 2(d)
].

FIG. 2.
Fabrication process of the PDMS grating: (a) pattering SU-8 mold on a PET substrate; (b) spin-coating and curing the thin PDMS film; (c) PDMS bonding to Ag mirror; and (d) separation of the SU-8 mold from the PDMS grating. Images of the fabricated sample are shown in (e).

Figure 2(e)
shows the actually fabricated PDMS grating. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images confirm that 2D patterns are uniformly transferred in an area of 60 × 60 mm
2
. Among four design variables, Λ,
w
g
, and
t
g
were measured from the cross-sectional view of the fabricated sample cut by a focused ion beam (FIB). A stylus profilometer (AS500, KLA Tencor) was also used to measure the PDMS film thickness
t
f
. The measured dimensions of each parameter are listed in
Table I
. Compared to the optimal structure, Λ,
w
g
, and
t
f
were able to be produced within a few percent error (
<
2
%
), but
t
g
exhibited 13.3% fabrication error. Fortunately, such fabrication errors cause only a marginal difference of the averaged emissivity (i.e., about 0.002) in the target wavelength range. If the fabrication errors cause substantial performance degradation, one can employ the robust optimization technique.
11
11. J. Choi, M. Kim, K. Kang, I. Lee, and B. J. Lee, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
209
, 129 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.01.028

It should be noted that the developed fabrication method is trichlorosilane-free and, thus, simpler and safer than the typical PDMS replication.
8,29
8. S. Lin, L. Ai, J. Zhang, T. Bu, H. Li, F. Huang, J. Zhang, Y. Lu, and W. Song, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
203
, 110135 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110135
29. F.-R. Fan, L. Lin, G. Zhu, W. Wu, R. Zhang, and Z. L. Wang, Nano Lett.
12
, 3109 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1021/nl300988z
Moreover, with the aid of the flexible PET substrate, PDMS can be readily separated and attached. Since thin PDMS films are easily torn apart during the large-area peeling, this process is desirable for better scalability. Although the PDMS grating was attached to the Ag film deposited on a Si wafer, it is expected to be applicable to any flexible or curved surfaces.

The spectral emissivity of the fabricated sample was measured by Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (FTLA 2000 series, ABB Bomem) with an integrating sphere. The average of five repeated measurements represents the measured spectral emissivity.
Figure 3(a)
shows the measured spectral emissivity of the optimal PDMS grating in the wavelength range of 7–14
μ
m. The averaged emissivity in the wavelength of 8–13
μ
m is found to be 0.99, which is the highest value among the previous polymer-based radiative coolers.
4–6,8,9,17–21
4. A. Srinivasan, B. Czapla, J. Mayo, and A. Narayanaswamy, Appl. Phys. Lett.
109
, 061905 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4961051
5. L. Zhou, H. Song, J. Liang, M. Singer, M. Zhou, E. Stegenburgs, N. Zhang, C. Xu, T. Ng, Z. Yu, B. Ooi, and Q. Gan, Nat. Sustainability
2
, 718 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-019-0348-5
6. J.-L. Kou, Z. Jurado, Z. Chen, S. Fan, and A. J. Minnich, ACS Photonics
4
, 626 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsphotonics.6b00991
8. S. Lin, L. Ai, J. Zhang, T. Bu, H. Li, F. Huang, J. Zhang, Y. Lu, and W. Song, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
203
, 110135 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110135
9. S. Y. Jeong, C. Y. Tso, Y. M. Wong, C. Y. H. Chao, and B. Huang, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
206
, 110296 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110296
17. Y. Zhai, Y. Ma, S. N. David, D. Zhao, R. Lou, G. Tan, R. Yang, and X. Yin, Science
355
, 1062 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aai7899
18. J. Mandal, Y. Fu, A. C. Overvig, M. Jia, K. Sun, N. N. Shi, H. Zhou, X. Xiao, N. Yu, and Y. Yang, Science
362
, 315 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aat9513
19. A. Aili, Z. Y. Wei, Y. Z. Chen, D. L. Zhao, R. G. Yang, and X. B. Yin, Mater. Today Phys.
10
, 100127 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mtphys.2019.100127
20. D. Fan, H. Sun, and Q. Li, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
195
, 250 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.03.019
21. A. R. Gentle and G. B. Smith, Adv. Sci.
2
, 1500119 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1002/advs.201500119
This measurement result is reliable because the standard deviation of averaged emissivity of five repeated measurements is only 0.001. For comparison purpose, the calculated emissivity spectrum is also plotted in the figure. For the simulated emissivity, the oscillation is observed in the wavelength range shorter than 8
μ
m as a result of the interference effect. These fringes are rarely detected in the measurement due to the limitation of the spectral resolution of the FT-IR spectrometer.
23
23. Z. M. Zhang,
Nano/Microscale Heat Transfer
(
McGraw-Hill
, 2007).
Considering the inevitable fabrication uncertainty, the agreement between the measured and calculated spectra is excellent.

FIG. 3.
(a) Calculated and measured emissivity spectra of the optimal PDMS grating. Air transmittance is also plotted together. (b) Comparison of the measured emissivity spectra of three samples. Black arrows indicate cavity resonant wavelengths.

To elucidate the physical mechanism responsible for enhanced infrared emission of the PDMS grating, we fabricated additional samples with different geometries. One is the same PDMS grating but with a thinner PDMS film thickness (i.e.,
t
f
=
25
μ
m
), and the other is the 105-
μ
m-thick bare PDMS film (i.e.,
t
g
=
0
μ
m
).
Figure 3(b)
compares the measured emissivity spectra of three samples. The dimensions of three PDMS samples are listed in
Table II
. Hereafter, we will call them simply as the optimal PDMS grating, thin PDMS grating, and bare PDMS film. By comparing the emissivity of bare PDMS film with those of PDMS gratings, it can be said that the lower emissivity regions located near 9–11 and 12–14
μ
m of the bare PDMS film are greatly enhanced with the use of grating structures. When the material refractive index is gradually increased along the incident path, the emissivity can be increased due to the anti-reflection effect, the so-called gradient refractive index effect.
8,9,30
8. S. Lin, L. Ai, J. Zhang, T. Bu, H. Li, F. Huang, J. Zhang, Y. Lu, and W. Song, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
203
, 110135 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110135
9. S. Y. Jeong, C. Y. Tso, Y. M. Wong, C. Y. H. Chao, and B. Huang, Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells
206
, 110296 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2019.110296
30. M. J. Minot, J. Opt. Soc. Am.
66
, 515 (1976).
https://doi.org/10.1364/JOSA.66.000515
Because this effect becomes more apparent in the spectral region where the imaginary part of the permittivity is large (refer to Fig. S2 in the
supplementary material
), the emissivity can be effectively enhanced in the vicinity of
λ
r
2
and
λ
r
4
. We observed that the spectral emissivity of optimal PDMS grating is larger than that of the bare PDMS film in the whole mid-infrared region (3–15
μ
m), that is, broadband enhancement is achieved by employing microscale grating structures.

TABLE II.
Dimension and measured emissivity of fabricated PDMS samples.

There exist three representative phenomena, resulting in the narrowband emission enhancement when the grating period is comparable with the wavelengths, i.e., surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs), magnetic polaritons (MPs), and cavity resonance.
23
23. Z. M. Zhang,
Nano/Microscale Heat Transfer
(
McGraw-Hill
, 2007).
As shown in
Fig. 4(a)
, because the real part of the PDMS permittivity is positive in the wavelength range of 8–13
μ
m, the PDMS grating cannot support SPPs and MPs unlike other polar materials (e.g., SiO
2
or SiC).
14,31
14. A. Hervé, J. Drévillon, Y. Ezzahri, and K. Joulain, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
221
, 155 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.09.015
31. L. P. Wang and Z. M. Zhang, Opt. Express
19
, A126 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1364/OE.19.00A126
On the other hand, the wavelength (
λ
r
) at which the cavity resonance occurs inside the PDMS grating itself can be determined by the following equation:
11,32,33
11. J. Choi, M. Kim, K. Kang, I. Lee, and B. J. Lee, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
209
, 129 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2018.01.028
32. H. Sai, Y. Kanamori, K. Hane, and H. Yugami, J. Opt. Soc. Am. A
22
, 1805 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1364/JOSAA.22.001805
33. F. Kusunoki, T. Kohama, T. Hiroshima, S. Fukumoto, J. Takahara, and T. Kobayashi, Jpn. J. Appl. Phys., Part 1
43
, 5253 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1143/JJAP.43.5253
λ
r
n
PDMS
=
2
(
l
L
x
)
2
+
(
m
L
y
)
2
+
(
n
2
L
z
)
2
,
(1)
where
n
PDMS
is the refractive index of PDMS at wavelength
λ
r
,
L
x
and
L
y
are the widths of the gratings,
L
z
is the height of the gratings, and (
l
,
m
,
n
) are integers (
l
,
m
=
0
,
1
,
2
,
…
and
n
=
0
,
1
,
3
,
5
,
…
). For the cavity resonance mode of (
l
,
m
,
n
) = (1, 0, 1) or (0, 1, 1), the five resonant wavelengths are supported within the 8–13
μ
m wavelength range, and they are labeled as
λ
r
1
,
λ
r
2
,
λ
r
3
,
λ
r
4
, and
λ
r
5
with black arrows in
Fig. 3(b)
.

FIG. 4.
(a) Real and imaginary parts of the PDMS permittivity. (b) Penetration depth of PDMS with respect to the wavelength. (c) Schematic of a FDTD simulation for unit PDMS grating. The squared magnitude of time-averaged electric field normalized by the incident electric field at (d)
λ
=
λ
r
1
, (e)
λ
=
λ
r
2
, and (f)
λ
=
λ
r
3
.

Those five resonant wavelengths are well matched with the spectral region where the emissivity of the bare PDMS film is lower than those of the PDMS grating. However, to enhance the radiative emission using the cavity resonance inside the PDMS grating, electromagnetic waves should propagate inside the PDMS cavity with minimal loss. Accordingly, we need to confirm whether the wave associated with the cavity resonance can propagate inside the PDMS grating through the penetration depth analysis. The penetration depth,
δ
λ
, is defined as
δ
λ
=
λ
4
π
κ
, where
κ
is the extinction coefficient.
23
23. Z. M. Zhang,
Nano/Microscale Heat Transfer
(
McGraw-Hill
, 2007).
Figure 4(b)
shows the penetration depth of PDMS on which five cavity resonant wavelengths (
λ
r
1
,
λ
r
2
,
λ
r
3
,
λ
r
4
, and
λ
r
5
) are also indicated. Because penetration depths at
λ
=
λ
r
1
,
λ
r
3
, and
λ
r
5
are longer than the dimension of unit PDMS grating, those cavity resonant modes can contribute to the enhancement of the spectral emissivity. On the other hand, at
λ
=
λ
r
2
and
λ
r
4
where the penetration depth is much shorter than the dimension of unit PDMS grating, the PDMS grating itself cannot play a role as a resonator.

The electric field distribution at cavity resonant wavelengths can provide evidence of the confinement of electromagnetic waves inside the PDMS grating.
Figure 4(c)
illustrates the schematic of a finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulation for unit PDMS grating. The electric field of the incident wave oscillates in the
y
-direction, and the observation plane of the electric field is on the
xz
-plane at the center of the grating (i.e., at
y
= 3.95
μ
m). The simulation dimension of the PDMS grating follows the fabricated structure described in
Table I
.
Figures 4(d)–4(f)
show contour plots of the squared magnitude of the time-averaged electric field normalized by the incident electric field for
λ
=
λ
r
1
,
λ
r
2
, and
λ
r
3
, respectively. In
Fig. 4(d)
at
λ
=
λ
r
1
and
Fig. 4(f)
at
λ
=
λ
r
3
, it can be evidently seen that the electric field is confined inside the PDMS grating. However, the electric field confinement is hardly observed in
Fig. 4(e)
at
λ
=
λ
r
2
since the
δ
λ
r
2
(i.e., 0.7
μ
m) is shorter than
w
g
. It is, thus, believed that the cavity resonance originated from the waveguide modes inside the cavity formed by PDMS grating can contribute to the emissivity enhancement in the 8–13
μ
m range when the size of PDMS grating is sufficiently small compared to its penetration depth.

We also investigate the effect of the PDMS film thickness (
t
f
) in
Fig. 3(b)
. When
t
f
is decreased, the notable emissivity reduction is observed near 7.4
μ
m and 10.6
μ
m. Because the dielectric materials like PDMS have small imaginary parts of the permittivity compared to metals [see
Fig. 4(a)
], absorption (or emission) in the PDMS film is rather a volumetric phenomenon,
34
34. S. Edalatpour and M. Francoeur, J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer
118
, 75 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2012.12.012
especially at 7.4
μ
m and 10.6
μ
m where the corresponding penetration depths are longer than other spectral regions [see
Fig. 4(b)
]. Therefore, the optimal PDMS grating exploits both the intrinsic absorption of PDMS and the cavity resonance associated with the grating structure. It is interesting to note that the averaged emissivity of the thin PDMS grating is still greater than that of the bare PDMS film (refer to
Table II
). Since a thinner film yields lower conductive thermal resistance, we believe that grating-patterned PDMS films will be advantageous for radiative cooling applications.

In summary, we have optimized the geometry of the grating-patterned PDMS film by utilizing an artificial neural network model and genetic algorithm to achieve the maximum averaged emissivity in the wavelength range between 8 and 13
μ
m. We have fabricated the optimal PDMS grating using a method applicable to diverse surfaces. The measured emissivity spectrum excellently agreed with the calculation and resulted in the largest averaged emissivity value of 0.99 among the polymer-based radiative coolers reported so far. Moreover, if we appropriately set the objective function of the optimization process, we will obtain the suitable structures to meet various radiative cooling situations. For instance, an optimal structure for the daytime radiative cooling can be derived by choosing the radiative cooling power as an objective function. Hence, the presented methods from optimization to fabrication will promote the implementation of high-performance polymer radiative coolers applicable to the various external conditions.

supplementary-material.div:
See the
supplementary material
for further results about the gradient refractive index effect.

div.div: AUTHORS' CONTRIBUTIONS
Section:
J.S. and J.S. contributed equally to this work.

This research was supported by the Basic Science Research Program (Nos. NRF-2020R1A2C3004885 and NRF-2020R1A4A4078930) and by the Creative Materials Discovery Program (No. NRF-2018M3D1A1058998) through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) funded by the Ministry of Science and ICT. This research was also supported by the Korea Institute of Energy Technology Evaluation and Planning (KETEP) and the Ministry of Trade, Industry & Energy (MOTIE) of the Republic of Korea (No. 20172010000850).
DATA AVAILABILITY
The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
